title: Bifrenaria
text:
Bifrenaria, abbreviated Bif. in horticultural trade, is a genus of <a href="plant">plant</a>s in family <a href="Orchidaceae">Orchidaceae</a>. It contains 20 species found in <a href="Panama">Panama</a>, <a href="Trinidad">Trinidad</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. There are no known uses for them, but their abundant, and at first glance artificial, <a href="flower">flower</a>s, make them favorites of orchid growers.
The genus can be split in two clearly distinct groups: one of highly robust plants with large flowers, that encompass the first species to be classified under the genus "Bifrenaria"; other of more delicate plants with smaller flowers occasionally classified as "Stenocoryne" or "Adipe". There are two additional species that are normally classified as "Bifrenaria", but which molecular analysis indicate to belong to different orchid groups entirely. One is "Bifrenaria grandis" which is endemic to <a href="Bol%C3%ADvia">Bolívia</a> and which is now placed in "<a href="Lacaena">Lacaena</a>", and "<a href="Bifrenaria%20steyermarkii">Bifrenaria steyermarkii</a>", an inhabitant of the northern <a href="Amazon%20Forest">Amazon Forest</a>, which does not have an alternative classification.
Description.
"Bifrenaria" are generally robust plants, of <a href="sympodial">sympodial</a> growth, between ten and sixty centimeters tall. They are characterized by round-section root with thick <a href="velamen">velamen</a>, four-angled fleshy <a href="pseudobulb">pseudobulb</a>s of one internode, often basally protected by dried sheaths and with only one apical <a href="leaf">leaf</a> (except for "Bifrenaria steyermarkii", which occasionally has two), plicate (fan-folded) enervated leathery leaves, yet malleable and not exceedingly thick, with a pseudo-petiole of basal round section, and a basal <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s bearing up to ten flowers, which seldom surpass the leaves' length.
"Bifrenaria" flowers are strongly scented, they have sepals slightly larger than the petals, with the lateral ones basally united to the <a href="column%20%28botany%29">column</a> foot forming a <a href="calcar">calcar</a> with truncated extremity. The column is slightly arching, generally without wings or any other appendages, bearing a foot which the labellum is hinged to, whose shape varies, articulated to the column, with a longitudinal channeled callus often with a basal claw. Flowers show two elongated <a href="stipe%20%28botany%29">stipe</a>s, hardy ever one, at least twice longer than wide, with salient <a href="viscidium">viscidium</a>, visible <a href="caudicle">caudicle</a>s and <a href="retinacle">retinacle</a> in inverted positions. The superposed <a href="pollinia">pollinia</a> number four, and are protected by a deciduous incumbent <a href="anther">anther</a>. Fruits are green, erect or pendulous; they take about eight months to ripe and hold hundreds of thousand yellowish or brownish elongated seeds up to 0.35 mm long. Among all the mentioned, the main characteristic distinguishing "Bifrenaria" from its closest relatives is the presence of the calcar. Other important characters are the four-sided single-leaved pseudobulbs besides the raceme inflorescence with two to ten flowers.
Little is known about pollination in "Bifrenaria". Apparently the only existing records report the presence of some large species' pollinia observed on the back of male "<a href="Eufriesea%20violacea">Eufriesea violacea</a>" bees (<a href="Euglossinae">Euglossinae</a>), and of "<a href="Bombus%20brasiliensis">Bombus brasiliensis</a>" (<a href="Bombini">Bombini</a>). Although there are no reports of flower pollination being directly observed, a paper published in 2006 studied the micromorphology of the labellum in "Bifrenaria" species, looking for substances useful to <a href="insect">insect</a>s as food. The absence of such substances on the densely pubescent surface of most "Bifrenaria" labelli seems to indicate possible pollination by large bees as the major mean. Another indicator of this possibility is the strong smell emanated by species like "B. tetragona" which are similar to those of plants in other families which are also pollinated by these bees. The smaller pubescent species may be pollinated by smaller bees, while the smooth ones, which have strong colored flowers, as "B. aureofulva", might be pollinated by <a href="hummingbird">hummingbird</a>s.
Taxonomy and phylogeny.
The first "Bifrenaria" species to be described was in 1824 by English Botanist <a href="William%20Jackson%20Hooker">William Jackson Hooker</a>, under the name "<a href="Bifrenaria%20harrisoniae">Dendrobium harrisoniae</a>". Three years later, he also described the first small-flowered species, "B. racemosa", but placed it in "<a href="Maxillaria">Maxillaria</a>". With these two publications began a long series of species descriptions and confusing genera creation which generated much doubt for the next two centuries. The <a href="Royal%20Botanic%20Gardens%2C%20Kew">Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew</a> registers the submission of 69 species or subspecific taxa under "Bifrenaria" since the description of the first species. Among these, twenty are generally accepted but only seventeen are truly well established, with no doubts about their limits and classification. Thirteen other species are still accepted but now placed in other genera, and four or five, due to deficiencies in their descriptions, might never be definitely identified.
In 1832, <a href="John%20Lindley">John Lindley</a> proposed the genus "Bifrenaria" and described its <a href="type%20species">type species</a>, "<a href="Bifrenaria%20atropurpurea">Bifrenaria atropurpurea</a>", previously named by <a href="Lodd.">Conrad Loddiges</a> as "Maxillaria atropurpurea". The name "Bifrenaria" comes from "bi", two, and "freno", brake, a reference to the shape of the two pairs of pollinia hold by separated caudicles presented by its flowers.
In 1837, <a href="Constantine%20Samuel%20Rafinesque">Constantine Samuel Rafinesque</a>, considering the noticeable vegetative difference between the few "Bifrenaria" known at the time, proposed the genus "Adipe", based on "B. racemosa" morphology, described by Hooker few years before, to which he added the description of a supposed new species, "Adipe fulva" (today treated as a synonym of "B. racemosa"). The next year Lindley received a specimen from Amazonia, which was morphologically even more distant from the known species, but nonetheless described it as "<a href="Bifrenaria%20longicornis">Bifrenaria longicornis</a>"'. Five years later, apparently not aware of Rafinesque's previous genus "Adipe", Lindley changed his mind and suggested that this species should be classified under a new genus, "Stenocoryne". Six species were subsequently attributed to "Stenocoryne" by various taxonomists, but the genus Rafinesque proposed remained unused until 1990.
Two species similar to "Bifrenaria", but that showed a highly salient claw at the base of the labellum and lateral lobes abruptly divided were then classified under this genus. In 1914, <a href="Friedrich%20Richard%20Rudolf%20Schlechter">Rudolf Schlechter</a> suggested they should be classified under the genus "<a href="Lindleyella">Lindleyella</a>", with Lindley's "<a href="Rudolfiella%20aurantiaca">Bifrenaria aurantiaca</a>" (which presented the mentioned differences) as the type. However this genus name was already occupied (It is a synonym of "<a href="Lindleya">Lindleya</a>", in the <a href="Rosaceae">Rosaceae</a>). Just thirty years later, in 1944, <a href="Frederico%20Carlos%20Hoehne">Frederico Carlos Hoehne</a>, working on the first revision of genus "Bifrenaria", corrected the suggestion of Schlechter. Hoehne initially proposed the genus "Schlechterella" for these species but, coincidentally, this name was also taken, this time by African "<a href="Asclepiadaceae">Asclepiadaceae</a>". Finally a genus with an available name in homage to Schlechter was erected in the very next issue of the journal, "<a href="Rudolfiella">Rudolfiella</a>", by which time the number of species had increased to seven. On this revision, besides "Rudolfiella", Hoehne divided "Bifrenaria" into two genera, accepting Lindley's "Stenocoryne" but calling attention to the existence of Rafinesque's "Adipe", which should have nomenclatural priority, while also raising doubts about the identity of several described species. In 1990, <a href="Manfred%20Wolff">Manfred Wolff</a> formally resurrected the genus "Adipe" and transferred to it ten "Bifrenaria" species, besides the two already described by Rafinesque; his change was purely nomenclatural and he did not revisit the species.
Making the picture even more complex, in 1994, Karheinz Senghas, based on several characteristics shared only by "B. tetragona" and "B. wittigii", described the genus "Cydoniorchis" to accommodate them. In 1996, Gustavo Romero and Germán Carnevali transferred to "Bifrenaria" a species originally described by Schlechter as "Maxillaria petiolaris" and now classified as "<a href="Hylaeorchis">Hylaeorchis petiolaris</a>". On the same year, Vitorino Castro Neto published a revision of "Bifrenaria", with five sections, which is the classification generally used today.
"Bifrenaria" has traditionally been classified in subtribe <a href="Bifrenariinae">Bifrenariinae</a> of tribe <a href="Maxillarieae">Maxillarieae</a> (<a href="Epidendroideae">Epidendroideae</a>), however, the relationships among the several genera within this tribe are not well defined and changes are expected in the upcoming years. The genus closest to "Bifrenaria" is "<a href="Rudolfiella">Rudolfiella</a>". Other related genera are "<a href="Teuscheria">Teuscheria</a>", "<a href="Guanchezia">Guanchezia</a>", "<a href="Hylaeorchis">Hylaeorchis</a>" and "<a href="Horvatia">Horvatia</a>", in addition to the more distant "<a href="Scuticaria%20%28plant%29">Scuticaria</a>" and "<a href="Xylobium">Xylobium</a>". The unification of subtribes <a href="Lycastinae">Lycastinae</a>, <a href="Maxillariinae">Maxillariinae</a> and <a href="Bifrenariinae">Bifrenariinae</a> has recently been suggested. However, there is no consensus on the path to be followed. Contrary to what was previously thought, the relationship among "Bifrenaria" and all these genera from <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> seems to indicate a primitive origin of "Bifrenaria" in <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> and its posterior dissemination towards the Southeast of Brazil, where it found fertile grounds to its more recent evolution.
In 2000, the first relatively complete molecular analysis on "Bifrenaria" species were made. Sixteen species from it and six of close genera were studied searching for confirmation of their phylogenetic relations, besides the delimitation of each species and each of "Bifrenaria"'s groups. The results did not allow for the acceptance of "Adipe" as a separate genus and, although they confirmed the monophyly of "Cydoniorchis" ("B. tetragona" and "B. wittigii"), they dissuade its recognition because six other genera would then be required to accommodate the remaining species. The study also expounded on convenience of splitting two species that are similar to each other and variable among themselves, but with many hard intermediate forms hard to delineate as "<a href="Bifrenaria%20charlesworthii">B. charlesworthii</a>" and "B. racemosa". It also confirmed the position of "B. steyermarkii" outside of "Bifrenaria", but without suggesting a new name.
Species.
"Bifrenaria" is formed by about twenty species divided in two main groups of plants, large and small, with some visible morphological subdivisions highly confirmed by <a href="phylogeny">phylogeny</a>.
Large species: is the group originally classified as "Bifrenaria". They present four sided <a href="pseudobulb">pseudobulb</a>s, with relatively short and erect inflorescence bearing up to ten fleshy large flowers but generally less. Usually the flowers are grouped and are fragrant or exhale strong scent. The labellum has three or four lobes and an elongated low callus. They are epiphytes, or often lithophytes. All originated in the southeast of Brazil. This group can be split in three subgroups:
Small species: is formed by the plants that once belonged to "Stenocoryne", or more accurately, "Adipe", which normally are epiphytes. They present smaller and not as noticeably four sided pseudobulbs, and long and delicate inflorescence bearing a higher medium number of flowers than the large species, although also never surpassing ten. The flowers are smaller and not fleshy, with an entire labellum, or sometimes slightly lobed on the apex. These species take less luminosity and more humidity than those and are not particularly fragrant. According to their morphology they can be split in four distinct subgroups:
Other species: the remaining species are plants about which classification consensus has not been achieved: "Bifrenaria maguirei", also classified under the genus "<a href="Guanchezia">Guanchezia</a>", and "Bifrenaria grandis", under "<a href="Lacaena">Lacaena</a>". "<a href="Bifrenaria%20steyermarkii">Bifrenaria steyermarkii</a>" is a species highly different from all other "Bifrenaria" because its inflorescence is very long ant its flowers highly narrow, therefore it does not fit in any group, nevertheless the only other option of classification that has been published so far is under "<a href="Xylobium">Xylobium</a>" what possibly is not a choice either.
Distribution and habitat.
"Bifrenaria" exist from the north of South America, one species reaching <a href="Trinidad">Trinidad</a>, until <a href="Rio%20Grande%20do%20Sul">Rio Grande do Sul</a>, the farther south State in <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, however they are split in two isolated areas: Amazon Forest and <a href="Atlantic%20Forest">Atlantic Forest</a> of Brazil. The later, where seventeen species are present, may be considered their recente center of distribution. The montane area of <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro%20State">Rio de Janeiro State</a> and <a href="Esp%C3%ADrito%20Santo">Espírito Santo</a> is particularly rich with fifteen species registered. <a href="Serra%20dos%20%C3%93rg%C3%A3os">Serra dos Órgãos</a> mountains area, in Rio, is reported as habitat of fourteen "Bifrenaria" species, however, some of these species are considered synonyms today, being eleven a more realistic number of species existing in the said area.
The species with large flowers are more common on <a href="Region%20Southeast%20of%20Brazil">Region Southeast of Brazil</a>, however, they inhabit from the sunnier areas of the seashore to rocky mountain areas of <a href="Minas%20Gerais">Minas Gerais</a> e <a href="Bahia">Bahia</a> States, from almost sea level up to 2,000 meters of <a href="altitude">altitude</a>, some species reaching <a href="Rio%20Grande%20do%20Sul">Rio Grande do Sul</a> state. No species of large flowers exist in Amazon Forest. Some species grow directly attached to the famous <a href="Sugarloaf%20Mountain">Sugarloaf Mountain</a> in Rio de Janeiro which can be observed by the commuters in the cable car. The recent centers of irradiation of this group are the seashore close to <a href="Serra%20do%20Mar">Serra do Mar</a> chain of mountains, and the high chains of mountains of Minas Gerais. The most common species in this group, spread from Rio Grande do Sul to Bahia, is "<a href="Bifrenaria%20harrisoniae">B. harrisoniae</a>".
The smaller species of "Bifrenaria", which some taxonomists classify under the genus "Adipe", are more common on less sunny areas and can be found between 300 and about 1,600 meters of altitude. Six species are native in Serra do Mar Chain of mountains and its arms, place considered the center of distribution of the small species. Only three small species inhabit Amazon, "<a href="Bifrenaria%20longicornis">B. longicornis</a>", which is more common at low artitudes; "<a href="Bifrenaria%20venezuelana">Bifrenaria venezuelana</a>", up to 1,450 meter of altitude, and "<a href="Bifrenaria%20steyermarkii">B. steyermarkii</a>" from even higher altitudes, in <a href="Roraima">Roraima</a> State, in Brasil, and nearby areas in <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and <a href="Surinam">Surinam</a>.
The most common species is "<a href="Bifrenaria%20aureofulva">B. aureofulva</a>", however, because the geographic characteristic of its territory, without obstacles, "<a href="Bifrenaria%20longicornis">B. longicornis</a>" is the species spread throughout the largest area, reaching <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Surinam">Surinam</a>, <a href="Guyana">Guyana</a>s, Trinidad and all Amazonic area in Brazil. Two species seem to be <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> in highly restricted areas: "<a href="Bifrenaria%20silvana">B. silvana</a>". discovered in 1987 at <a href="Serra%20da%20Ouricana">Serra da Ouricana</a> mountains, nearby <a href="Itoror%C3%B3">Itororó</a>, in <a href="Bahia">Bahia</a> which belongs to "Adipe" group; and "<a href="Bifrenaria%20verboonenii">B. verboonenii</a>", discovered in September 1995 on <a href="Serra%20do%20Cip%C3%B3">Serra do Cipó</a> mountains, close to <a href="Diamantina%2C%20Minas%20Gerais">Diamantina</a>, <a href="Minas%20Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>, of the large "Bifrenara" group.
"Bifrenaria" species inhabit three different environments. The large species generally live in well illuminated areas, occasionally <a href="Epiphytically">epiphyte</a> on trees of sparse foliage, more often as <a href="lithophyte">lithophyte</a>s, in <a href="campos%20rupestres">campos rupestres</a>, montane rocky areas that exist mostly in Rio and Minas Gerais States of Brazil, or over rocks in jungle's clearances. "B. tyrianthina" is exclusively lithophyte, "B. tetragona" and "B. wittigii" hardly ever do. "B. atropurpurea" is the only species found living terrestrially, but in rare occasions. The large species always show .
The small species from Southeast Brazil live in <a href="cloud%20montane%20forest">cloud montane forest</a>s, where the appear in much darker places than the large species. Within this sort of forests the <a href="temperature">temperature</a> presents noticeable difference between day and night and also through the seasons. These also are plants of <a href="caespitous%20growth">caespitous growth</a>, almost all epiphytes, despite there is at least one record of "Bifrenaria aureofulva" living lithophylically in <a href="Chapada%20Diamantina">Chapada Diamantina</a>, Bahia.
The species from Amazon inhabit tropical <a href="lowland">lowland</a> forests and <a href="equatorial%20forest">equatorial forest</a>s. "Bifrenaria longicornis" is mostly found in flood areas along the <a href="igap%C3%B3">igapó</a>s and <a href="igarap%C3%A9">igarapé</a>s (seasonal flood streams and small rivers of Amazon), and occasionally in open fields where the <a href="humidity">humidity</a> is high and <a href="temperature">temperature</a> constant through the year, normally in well illuminated places, although not under direct <a href="sunlight">sunlight</a>. "B. venezuelana" inhabits forests in higher elevations, closer to the <a href="Andes">Andes</a>. Amazon species are epiphyte and the only "Bifrenaria" species with elongated <a href="rhizome">rhizome</a> and <a href="ascendant%20growth">ascendant growth</a>.
Cultivation.
"Bifrenaria" are comparatively easy to grow orchids. They should be preferably potted on well drained vegetable fiber because their roots and pseudobulbs rot easily when kept humid for long periods. One of three different environments is needed depending on the species' origin to successfully grow these plants. The larger species need more light than the others. The smaller species from Southeast Brazil may be cultivated at the same medium temperature but under less than 10-20% <a href="luminosity">luminosity</a>. "Bifrenaria" from the Amazon Forest require higher and more constant <a href="temperature">temperature</a> and <a href="humidity">humidity</a> than other species. All species need most <a href="water">water</a> and <a href="fertilizer">fertilizer</a> during their active growth season.
